description: From Middle English sloberen, borrowed from Middle Dutch slobberen (> Modern Dutch slobberen (“to slobber”)), related to West Frisian slobberje (“to slurp”), German Low German slubbern (“to slobber”). Doublet of slabber and slaver. Compare also German schlabbern (“to slobber”). Not related to English slob.

entries.meaning: Liquid material, generally saliva, that dribbles or drools outward and downward from the mouth.
examples: There was dried slobber on his coat lapel.

verbs.description: slobber (third-person singular simple present slobbers, present participle slobbering, simple past and past participle slobbered)

entries.meaning: To allow saliva or liquid to run from one's mouth.
